Aged Sixty-seven

Dr. Greene was born 67 years
ago at Newton, Mass. He studied
at Harvard University where he
received the A. B. degree, then
went to Germany and France
where he studied for two yeirs,
returning to the United States, to
take the .M. A. and Ph. D. degrees
at Harvard.
From Harvard, Dr. Greene
went to Wells College, as an instructor, and he was at that institution when President Gilman, of
Hopkins, offered him the position
of Collegiate Professor of English,
in 1893. Dr. Greene accepted, and
since that time has taught at Hop-

Profs Score Mencken

When asked their opinions on
Mr. Mencken's article, three university professors criticized him
severely, at the same time advising not to take Mencken too seriously. Four others declined to
be quoted,
Dr. R. B. Roulston. profess°.
of German, said: "Why Mencken doesn't know any more about
the Johns Hopkins University
than a cow does about the intricacies of music. If he would come
out with some real facts, we
should be glad to listen to him.
Mencken doesn't know six men in
Johns Hopkins, and has probably
never set foot in the place."
Dr. J. C. French, professor of
English, said: "He doesn't know
what he's talking about. If President Gilman had lived; I feel sure
he would have continued his policy as it is now continued."
Dr. L. S. Hulbert, collegiate
professor Of Mathematics', remarked: "I am glad he approves
of the plan. However, he seems
to criticize President Goodnow ;
this, of course, I cannot sympathize with."

Publicity for spring sports at
Hopkins will be the aim of the
Johns Hopkins Publicity Board
from now until June, according to
the policy decided upon at a meeting of that organization held last
Wednesday in the Barn.
Handicapped by a lack of funds,
and by the inability to secure adequate space in which. to work, the
Board has not been very active
during the past year. Its chief
energy was devoted to advertising the Musical Club's southern
concert tour, and the success of
that campaign is evidenced by the
numerous clippings from publications in Norfolk, Petersburg
d Richmond, giving news of the
Club's concerts.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
A gift of $1,500,000 from John
D. Rockefeller has made possible
the building of a new chapel at
the University of Chicago. Mr.
Rockefeller, who is the founder of
the university, recently gave the
institution $10,000,000 with the
stipulation that $1,500,000 be used
in the construction of a new
chapel.
The chapel, which when finished will occupy an entire city
block, will be one of the largest
and most beautiful buildings of its
type in the Middle West. It will
be, architecturally, a Gothic cathedral, with a nave 41 feet wide, a
channel, a west transept, and opposite this on the east a transeptal
tower 200 feet high. The seating
capacity of the chapel will be 2000.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 20. 1925
HOPKINS MARKSMEN TAKE
GETTYSBURG INTO CAMP
IN RIFLE MATCH
Score

1809 Points to Opponents'
1745; Are Tie for Second
Place in League

Led by the accurate shooting of
Rawlins, the Hopkins rifle team
scored a decisive victory over the
Gettysburg College marksmen at
the Homewood range last Saturday.
The scOre was 1-,809 to 1,745: The
respective scores of the local team
Were: Rawlins 371, Hall 369, Baird
367, Garis 354, and Reiblich 348.
The Homewood aggregation has not
lost a shoulder-to-shoulder competition this year. Last week's victory was the third consecutive win.
Up until last week, the Hopkins
Sharpshooters were in a tie for first
Place in the Eastern Collegiate
League. However, as a result of
recent losses to George Washington
and Georgetown, the locals were
Shoved into second place. George
Washington and Georgetown are at
Present setting the pace with five
victories and no defeats. These two
teams will soon meet to decide the
leadership.

THE JOHNS HOPKLNS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 20, 1925
MUSICAL CLUB TO GIVE
FINAL CONCERT AT
GIST SCHOOL
Rearranged Program Featuring the
Blue Jay Orchestra Expected to
Receive Warm Welcome

Tonight the Johns _Hopkins
Musical Club will close the most
successful season in is history by
giving a concert at the Mordecai
Gist School No. 69, Granada and
Oakford Avenues:, Forest Park.
The curtain is to rise at 8.15, disclosing many of the faces which
have made the Club so well known
and well liked.
Sponsored by Mothers

"The concert," said President
Tilghman, "is under the auspices
of the Mothers' Club of School No.
69. The program is to be entirely
rearranged, with different numbers and a new sequence. J. J.
Scherr and the Blue Jay Twelve
will play their selections immediately after the intermission which
divides the concert into two parts:
when their numbers are concluded, they will leave for the Maryland Theatre, there to drive another audience into an enthusiastic demonstration." Mr. Tilghman
also stated that he expected to see
all of the 500 seats in the hall
filled.

THE FLAME THAT FIRES
COLLEGE

athletic teams illustrate
forcibly one truth men achieve by
inspiration. The bleachers' cry of
"Hold 'ern! Hold 'ern!" has kept
many a goal line uncrossed. "Touchdown! Touchdown! has scored
countless victories.
In an engineering organization
like Westinghouse, this inspiration
comes from engineering executives—
men who correlate, organize, administrate, and inspire. They are engineers first, but engineers with the
power to enlist the best ofother men.
Many derived their own first inspiration from the Founder, George

Westinghouse himself. He took a
contract for electrifying the New
Haven Railroad, for example, before
the apparatus had even been designed.
"Now I've dropped you into the
middle of the pond," he told his engineers. "It's up to you to swim out."
There was plenty of swimming—
butWestinghouse knewhis swimmers.
As has been true since organization began, the demand for men who
can develop into leaders is far, far
short of the supply. Westinghouse
welcomes them. All industry welcomes them. Organizations lead because men, in turn, lead them.

fields for engineering achievement in the Westinghouse organi7ation.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
A gift of $1,500,000 from John
D. Rockefeller has made possible
the building of a new chapel at
the University of Chicago. Mr.
Rockefeller, who is the founder of
the university, recently gave the
institution $10,000,000 with the
stipulation that $1,500,000 be used
in the construction of a new
chapel.
The chapel, which when finished will occupy an entire city
block, will be one of the largest
and most beautiful buildings of its
type in the Middle West. It will
be, architecturally, a Gothic cathedral, with a nave 41 feet wide, a
channel, a west transept, and opposite this on the east a transeptal
tower 200 feet high. The seating
capacity of the chapel will be 2000.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 20. 1925
HOPKINS MARKSMEN TAKE
GETTYSBURG INTO CAMP
IN RIFLE MATCH
Score

1809 Points to Opponents'
1745; Are Tie for Second
Place in League

Led by the accurate shooting of
Rawlins, the Hopkins rifle team
scored a decisive victory over the
Gettysburg College marksmen at
the Homewood range last Saturday.
The scOre was 1-,809 to 1,745: The
respective scores of the local team
Were: Rawlins 371, Hall 369, Baird
367, Garis 354, and Reiblich 348.
The Homewood aggregation has not
lost a shoulder-to-shoulder competition this year. Last week's victory was the third consecutive win.
Up until last week, the Hopkins
Sharpshooters were in a tie for first
Place in the Eastern Collegiate
League. However, as a result of
recent losses to George Washington
and Georgetown, the locals were
Shoved into second place. George
Washington and Georgetown are at
Present setting the pace with five
victories and no defeats. These two
teams will soon meet to decide the
leadership.

THE JOHNS HOPKLNS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 20, 1925
MUSICAL CLUB TO GIVE
FINAL CONCERT AT
GIST SCHOOL
Rearranged Program Featuring the
Blue Jay Orchestra Expected to
Receive Warm Welcome

Tonight the Johns _Hopkins
Musical Club will close the most
successful season in is history by
giving a concert at the Mordecai
Gist School No. 69, Granada and
Oakford Avenues:, Forest Park.
The curtain is to rise at 8.15, disclosing many of the faces which
have made the Club so well known
and well liked.
Sponsored by Mothers

"The concert," said President
Tilghman, "is under the auspices
of the Mothers' Club of School No.
69. The program is to be entirely
rearranged, with different numbers and a new sequence. J. J.
Scherr and the Blue Jay Twelve
will play their selections immediately after the intermission which
divides the concert into two parts:
when their numbers are concluded, they will leave for the Maryland Theatre, there to drive another audience into an enthusiastic demonstration." Mr. Tilghman
also stated that he expected to see
all of the 500 seats in the hall
filled.

Final Presentation

But whereas this is to be the
last time the Glee Club and Banjo
Club appear on the stage, the Orchestra has yet to perform at the
Colonial Theatre in Richmond
during the Easter Holidays. "This
is the •best season we have ever
had," said Manager J. J. Scherr of
the Blue Jays. "We have received
more bids than we could possibly
accept ; and those that we have
taken up are such as will bring us
lasting popularity and publicity."
Besides these important engagements, the thirteen syncopators
are to play at practically every
Hopkins dance for the remainder
of the year.
SEASON TICKET CAMPAIGN
Continued from page 1

The campaign' will have demonstrated fully that the undergraduates have not taken seriously to
the work of supporting the teams
and needs of the athletic department of the University.
Should it become imperative to
continue an active sale of spring
season tickets after the receipts
of the present campaign have
been totalled, picked men, according to Keyes, may be sent out to
sell on a commission basis. It
will be profitable for the men who
are selected, to devote entire days
to the selling of tickets.

BMDERS

THE FLAME THAT FIRES
COLLEGE

athletic teams illustrate
forcibly one truth men achieve by
inspiration. The bleachers' cry of
"Hold 'ern! Hold 'ern!" has kept
many a goal line uncrossed. "Touchdown! Touchdown! has scored
countless victories.
In an engineering organization
like Westinghouse, this inspiration
comes from engineering executives—
men who correlate, organize, administrate, and inspire. They are engineers first, but engineers with the
power to enlist the best ofother men.
Many derived their own first inspiration from the Founder, George

Westinghouse himself. He took a
contract for electrifying the New
Haven Railroad, for example, before
the apparatus had even been designed.
"Now I've dropped you into the
middle of the pond," he told his engineers. "It's up to you to swim out."
There was plenty of swimming—
butWestinghouse knewhis swimmers.
As has been true since organization began, the demand for men who
can develop into leaders is far, far
short of the supply. Westinghouse
welcomes them. All industry welcomes them. Organizations lead because men, in turn, lead them.

This advertisement is seventh in a vocational series, outlining the
fields for engineering achievement in the Westinghouse organi7ation.
A copy of the entire series will be sent to anyone requesting it.
